senses.de: Happening a lot, or doing something a lot.
senses.ex: She is a frequent visitor to the museum.

Tips.title: Intensity Indicator
Tips.description: Describes something that happens very often, indicating a high level or degree of something.
Tips.example: Due to his frequent absences, he struggled to catch up.

Tips.title: Expect Regularity
Tips.description: Implies an established pattern or habit in occurrences or actions.
Tips.example: Her frequent exercise sessions led to a major health improvement.

Tips.title: Preceding Nouns
Tips.description: Often used before nouns to describe objects or events that happen regularly.
Tips.example: I have to deal with frequent interruptions during my work.

senses.ex: He frequents the local coffee shop every morning.

Tips.title: Show Habituality
Tips.description: When used as a verb, it conveys a routine or habit of visiting a place regularly.
Tips.example: She frequents the library, especially during exam season.

Tips.title: Implies Liking
Tips.description: Suggests a preference for a place or activity without explicitly saying it.
Tips.example: If a person frequents a restaurant, they likely enjoy the food or atmosphere.

Tips.title: Not Just Physical
Tips.description: Can also refer to regularly visiting virtual places, like websites or online forums.
Tips.example: Many gamers frequent online forums to discuss strategies.

senses.ex: This is a frequent topic in our discussions.

Tips.title: Not Always Actual
Tips.description: While it implies being common, it doesn't always mean something is present at the moment.
Tips.example: That issue is a frequent concern, though it hasn't happened today.

Tips.title: Subjective Frequency
Tips.description: What's considered 'frequent' can vary depending on a person's perspective or experience.
Tips.example: In his book, 'frequent victories' means winning most matches, not all.

Tips.title: Indicates Prevalence
Tips.description: Signifies that something is widespread or happens often enough to be noticeable.
Tips.example: Frequent references to sustainability can be found in her speeches.

Common.wordDefinition:
Both common and frequent denote something occurring often, but common means "having attributes or characteristics that are usual, belonging to a group or society as a whole" whereas frequent means "happening often or regularly".

For example, "it is common for people to eat breakfast every morning" means it is normal or typical behavior for people to do so.

In summary, “common” suggests something is normal or usual, whereas “frequent” simply refers to something that happens often.

Constant.wordDefinition:
Constant means something that doesn't change or remains the same all the time, without interruption.

For example, if a person has a constant headache, it means they have a headache that doesn't go away. If a person frequently gets a headache, it means they experience headaches often but not necessarily all the time.

Customary.wordDefinition:
Customary refers to something that is considered normal or traditional within a particular culture or society. For example, it is customary to shake hands when meeting someone in American culture.

Customary describes something that is considered normal or traditional within a particular culture or society, while frequent describes something that happens often or regularly.

Habitual.wordDefinition:
Frequent means happening often or repeatedly, while habitual means done regularly or as a habit.

For example, if someone eats ice cream frequently, they might eat it once or twice a week. If someone has a habitual behavior of eating ice cream, they might eat it every night after dinner.

Frequent describes how often something happens, while habitual describes a pattern of behavior or routine.

Recurrent.wordDefinition:
Frequent means happening often, while the word recurrent means happening repeatedly.

For example, if you go to the beach every weekend, then your visits to the beach are frequent. If you get a cold every few weeks, then the cold is recurrent.

Frequent applies to things that happen often, while recurrent applies to things that happen repeatedly.

Regular.wordDefinition:
Regular means to occur on a set schedule or at equally spaced intervals. For example, if you have a regular appointment with the dentist, it occurs at the same time and day each month or year.

Frequent describes something that happens often, while regular describes something that happens at a set interval.

Repeat.wordDefinition:
Frequent means something that happens often or occurs repeatedly but not necessarily in a pattern. For example, a person who goes to the gym frequently visits it often, but their visits may not be on a set schedule.

Repeat means to do something again, exactly the same way as before. For instance, if a person repeats a song they heard, they sing or play it again in the same way they did before.

Frequent refers to something happening often, while repeat pertains to doing something again in the same way as before.

Usual.wordDefinition:
Usual means something that is normal or expected. For example, if someone asks you what your usual order is at a coffee shop, they are asking what your normal order is.

Frequent describes how often something happens, while usual describes what is typical or normal.

quotes.Text: Every time I travel, I'm in a rage until I reach my destination. I find myself shouting at suitcases, as if it's their fault that I'm an inefficient packer. I've also learnt that whenever you despair of humanity and start thinking that you hate people - as I frequently do - you only have to travel to realise that people are basically all right.
quotes.Title: British Comedian
quotes.Name: Greg Davies

quotes.Text: I want to be part of the storytelling that educates people and awakens a sense of compassion in other people of the kind of people they don't encounter in their daily lives very frequently.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Kelly McCreary

quotes.Text: Life with a scientist who is often changing jobs and is frequently away at meetings and on lecture tours is not easy. Without a secure home base, I could not have made much progress.
quotes.Title: English Scientist
quotes.Name: John Pople

quotes.Text: I actually don't think that I'm that much smarter than anybody else. It's just that I frequently just seem to know what to do, and I think that's wisdom.
quotes.Title: American Scientist
quotes.Name: Ben Carson

quotes.Text: Leaders of organisations, political parties and large businesses frequently fail to talk in a straight and entirely truthful fashion.
quotes.Title: Scottish Journalist
quotes.Name: Gavin Esler

quotes.Text: My husband will tell you one of the most frequent questions he gets from world leaders is, 'How's your wife's garden?
quotes.Title: American First Lady
quotes.Name: Michelle Obama

quotes.Text: For life is but a dream whose shapes return, some frequently, some seldom, some by night and some by day.
quotes.Title: Scottish Musician
quotes.Name: James Thomson

quotes.Text: I have frequently gained my first real insight into the character of parents by studying their children.
quotes.Title: British Writer
quotes.Name: Arthur Conan Doyle

quotes.Text: In those days he was wiser than he is now; he used to frequently take my advice.
quotes.Title: British Statesman
quotes.Name: Winston Churchill

quotes.Text: I do not speak frequently or otherwise to the press.
quotes.Title: American Lawyer
quotes.Name: Ken Starr
